comments.text:
Hah! You got me at machine gun. I definitely agree that this isn't the best 
way to speak. But compared to the rest of YouTube this isn't THAT fast at 
all. :) Although I absolutely envy the articulation these people 
(especially on Youtube) administer at such an immense pace and equally 
gigantic volume (of info) without getting tongue-tied, as a listener I 
often end up feeling tense at the end. I'm British and I've only seen one 
Brit speak at this speed and that person was reading aloud from a 
book! This type of mega fast speech really gets my wires crossed as much as 
Spritz crosses my eyes :P. So for someone like me it isn't the greatest 
method. I feel I'm missing big parts of the talk and my brain goes on 
override. But I've met enough Americans to know not many people speak this 
way and I think on YouTube it has more to do with the time it takes for us 
to lose interest while watching one video and exactly how much useful 
information you can fit into that span of time. That's especially so, the 
more intellectual the topic is. Editing probably has some type of role as 
well in the way speech is sped up and divided into verbal clumps so it is 
more efficient(?) when editing for internet videos. But that's just a 
guess. Also, I don't know about this channel but a lot of well thought out 
videos like this actually have a script or at least a mock of one and 
knowing what you're going to say beforehand obviously quickens speech. All 
in all, if this guy were speaking at a slower pace and the clip were 
longer, my head would spin less, but I have a nagging feeling I'd be really 
bored especially with educational channels like this :).

top_comment.text:
So many pro-Russian and pro-American comments on here that don't have any 
real weight behind them. Comments such as 'your argument is dumb' 'you are 
bias' and 'you lose credibility by making childish statements', yet not A 
SINGLE ONE provides any quotes from the video itself to back up these 
claims. The problem on both sides of this issue is that propaganda ensures 
some individuals become so sure that their side is the right one that they 
fight tooth and nail to protect them, without any real knowledge of the 
events, and/or any willingness to listen to the arguments of the other 
side. And this transcends past Youtube and into politics and the rest of 
society; modern day propaganda is so well constructed that so many 
individuals refuse to listen to another side of the argument because they 
have been told from television, the internet and other forms of media that 
the other side is the one making all the mistakes. The spread of 
disinformation really doesn't help with this either, with massive news 
networks on all sides spreading half truths and straight up lies to further 
the political agenda of the country, and only a very small minority able to 
find out the real story (which at times still is not the accurate truth 
that many claim it to be). It's time to break down the east/west barrier 
that didn't fall during the end of the cold war, and finally have some 
clarity and communication between all superpowers, because if not we will 
be doomed to repeat the mistakes of the past. Ironically, the only saving 
grace in today's world is Nuclear weaponry and M.A.D., which is both a 
terrible blessing and a potentially catastrophic time bomb, both making the 
use of nuclear weaponry incredibly unlikely, whilst ensuring that if any 
nuclear weaponry is used, a global catastrophe is inevitable.

Inb4 tl;dr.
Also, if anything I've said offends you, perhaps it's because it's you I'm 
talking about.﻿

comments.text:
+MrPessimisticrealist There's a great documentary by BBC on Putin that can 
make the Ukraine crisis a bit clearer, although more confusing at the same 
time. It's called "Putin, Russia and the West", more specifically the 
second episode "Democracy Threatens". It's about the 2004 election and the 
Orange Revolution. I highly recommend all 4 episodes, though.

IMHO the situation is quite complex because there's the suspicion the west 
is behind the recent "revolution", which would prompt Putin to behave like 
he is (especially because of American intentions of installing military 
equipment near Russia's border). On the other hand Putin was an asshole in 
the Georgia-Russia conflict and looks like he's doing to same to Ukraine 
now (even though they had legitimate reasons to worry about Georgia, since 
Chechen rebels fled to the Pankisi Gorge and Georgia did nothing to prevent 
them from attacking Russia).

There's a history of conflicts too long and intense with many moments of 
greed, betrayal and resentment that makes both sides act more extremely 
than they should. Which sucks. And as usual the citizens suffer while 
arrogant politicians fight for power.

top_comment.text:
As a frequent visitor to Ukraine, I would take issue with your map of 
Russian-speaking versus Ukrainian-speaking population. 

I have seen the same map shown on many US TV stations and there are three 
basic problems with the map:

1. It is an absolute distortion of the truth. 100% of the population of 
Ukraine speak Russian daily in their lives. After all, Ukraine was a part 
of Russia for decades. The languages are remarkably similar. The chart was 
produced by the Ukrainian government - the same government that spent tens 
of millions of dollars in 2010 replacing every Russian-language street sign 
with Ukrainian street signs...this in a country with severe economic 
problems and huge debt...and remember everyone speaks and can read Russian 
in Ukraine. So you see this map is a political statement by the government, 
not at all accurate. If you go to Kiev, the east, or the west of Ukraine, 
you will hear people speaking both the Russian and Ukrainian language. It 
is the primary language of business in Ukraine as well.

2. Even if the map was accurate, which it is not, the primary language of a 
person doesn't tell you which way they lean politically in this crisis. 
Someone who does not speak Ukrainian as their primary language may be a 
fierce Ukrainian nationalist, and visa versa. So the primary language of a 
person cannot be used as a proxy or straw poll for whether they are 
pro-Russian or pro-Ukraine...and most Ukrainians are both pro-Russian and 
pro-Ukraine. It is not an either/or proposition.

As an aside, calling Yulia Tymoshenko "slightly corrupt" is the most kind 
characterization of her dishonesty I have ever heard. She is a bold-faced 
liar and manipulator who stole billions of dollars from the Ukraine 
treasury, was imprisoned for her crimes (with almost unanimous praise for 
the verdict, and little public protest), and is not well-regarded by the 
citizens of Ukraine. That is why she was quickly yanked from the political 
stage during the latest celebration in Kiev square.

Your facts on Ukraine's history are 90% accurate and you give a good 
summary of Ukraine's history, but please don't show that map again, it is a 
piece of propaganda, not an accurate depiction of language used in Ukraine, 
and certainly not a reason for the US and Eurozone to try and split a 
united country down the middle. Don't give Putin another excuse to split 
Ukraine further.﻿

The problem with the "referendum" in Crimea is that there was no 
international oversight to insure it was fair, there was no anonymity at 
the ballot (which means you put yourself at risk for voting against the 
occupying force), the only options where to become independent or part of 
Russia (automatic invalidation of the vote under international law), and 
there was the threat from occupation forces. One of these would make the 
vote at best questionable and likely invalidate it, all four invalidate it 
without question.

and only about 40% supported joining Russia, and almost no Ukrainians or 
Tatars did. Given that only 60% of Crimea is ethnic Russian, but over 80% 
showed up at the polls, the fact that almost all voted to join Russia is 
unimaginable in a real, fair referendum.

This is only one version of the meaning and many serious linguist consider 
this etymology to be a kind of a folk etymology. Russia likes this folk 
theory of Ukraine being just a border land, a territory, not real country 
because it fits their contempt towards Ukrainian nation. Actually the 
original name of the country which is called Ukraine today - was "Ukraina 
Rus" which meant "Country Rus"  
http://img.tyzhden.ua/Content/Digest/week/june/1.06/map.jpg [kraj] - is a 
root which may mean edge/border, but it also means 'something with borders" 
= country, nation. Same or similar Slavic word for country is used by other 
Slavic languages. Even in Russia there are several kraj's/kray's which are 
not on the border and present rather large territory.
- and by the way, do not confuse Rus and Russia. The place which we call 
Russia today up to 17th century was called "Moskovskaya Tataria" or simply 
"Moscovia". 
http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:1574_Ruscelli_Map_of_Russia_(Muscovy)_and_Ukraine_-_Geographicus_-_Moschovia-porcacchi-1572.jpg
  
Trying to revive old glory of Kievan Rus, Moscovia kind of 'borrowed" the 
name Rus in the form of Russia (Rossia) and never gave it back to Ukraine.

comments.text:
We have been led to believe that in order to industrialize at any price 
Stalin pursued a ruthless policy of forced collectivization deliberately 
murdering several million peasants known as kulaks during the process. The 
truth is quite different however.
When the Bolsheviks seized power one of their first acts was to legalize 
the seizure of the huge landed estates from the feudalistic landlords. The 
slogan of this campaign was
"Land to the tiller." This however, left most land in the form of small 
holdings unsuited for large-scale agriculture particularly the production 
of the vital grain crops necessary to provide for the urban centers. Under 
the NEP, agrarian capitalism and a new form of exploitative landlordism 
began to flourish in the countryside. The class known as kulaks, literally 
"tight-fists", consisting of usurer lenders and other petite capitalists 
including village merchants and rich peasants, were cornering the market in 
the available grain grabbing more and more small holdings of land, and, 
through their debt holdings, coercing peasants back into tenant farming and 
wage labor. Somehow, the small peasant holdings had to be consolidated so 
that modern agriculture could begin. There were basically two ways this 
could take place. Either through capitalist accumulation, as the kulaks 
were then doing, or through the development of large-scale socialist farms. 
If the latter, there was then a further choice: a rapid forced 
collectivization, or a more gradual process in which co-operative farms 
would emerge first, followed by collectives, and both would be on a 
voluntary basis, winning out by example and persuasion. What did Stalin 
choose?

Here, in his own words, is the policy he advocated and that was adopted at 
the Fifteenth Party Congress, in 1927.
"What is the way out? The way out is to turn the small and scattered 
peasant farms into large united farms based on cultivation of the land in 
common, to go over to collective cultivation of the land on the basis of a 
new and higher technique.
The way out is to unite the small and dwarf peasant farms gradually but 
surely, not by pressure, but by example and persuasion, into large farms 
based on common, cooperative, collective cultivation of the land with the 
use of agricultural machines and tractors and scientific methods of 
intensive agriculture.
There is no other way out."

To implement this policy, the capitalist privileges allowed under the NEP 
to redevelop industry to the necessary phase of development where a 
transition to vanguard socialism could begin, were revoked. This was known 
as the restriction of the kulaks. The kulaks, whose very existence as an 
exploiting class was thus menaced, struck back. They organized terrorist 
bands who attacked the co-operatives and collectives, burning down barns 
when they were filled with grain, devastating the fields, and even 
murdering Communist peasant leaders. Even more serious than these raids, 
the kulaks held back their own large supplies of grain from the market in 
an effort to create hunger and chaos in the urban centers.

The poor and middle peasants struck back. Virtual open civil war began to 
rage throughout the countryside. As the collective farm movement spread 
rapidly, pressure mounted among the poor and middle peasants to put an end 
to cruel landlordism and loan usury in the countryside for good. In 1929 
Stalin agreed that the time had come to eliminate the kulaks as a class. He 
led the fight to repeal the laws that allowed the renting of land and the 
hiring of labor, thus depriving the kulaks both of land and of hired 
workers. The ban on expropriation of the large private holdings was lifted, 
and the peasants promptly expropriated the kulak class. The expropriation 
of the rural agrarian capitalists in the late 1920s was just as decisive as 
the expropriation of the urban industrial capitalists a decade earlier. 
Rural landlords and village usurers were eliminated as completely as 
private factory owners for their exploitation of the masses. It is 
undoubtedly true that in many areas there was needless violence and 
suffering. But this did not originate with Stalin. It was the hour of the 
countries rural peasant masses, who had been degraded and brutalized for 
centuries and who had countless blood debts to settle with their 
oppressors. Stalin may have unleashed their fury, but he was not the one 
who had caused it to build up for centuries.

In fact it was Stalin who checked the excesses generated by the enthusiasm 
of the collective movement. In early 1930 he published in Pravda "Dizzy 
with Success", reiterating that "the voluntary principle" of the collective 
farming movement must under no circumstances be violated and that anybody 
who engages in coercive collectivization objectively aids the enemies of 
socialism. Furthermore, he argues, the correct form for the present time is 
the cooperative, known as the artel, in which "the household plots, small 
vegetable gardens, small orchards, the dwelling houses, a part of the dairy 
cattle, small livestock, poultry, etc., are not socialized." Again, 
overzealous attempts to push beyond this objectively aid the enemy. The 
movement must be based on the needs and desires of the masses of peasants.

Stalin’s decision about the kulaks perfectly exemplifies the limits under 
which he operated. He could decide, as he did, to end the kulaks as a class 
by allowing the poor and middle peasants’ to expropriate their land. Or he 
could decide to let the kulaks continue withholding their grain from the 
starving peasants and workers, with whatever result. He might have 
continued bribing the kulaks. But it is highly doubtful, to say the least, 
that he had the option of persuading the kulaks into becoming good 
socialists.
comments.author: Sheogorath Daedric Princess of Douchebaggery

comments.text:
Excerpt from an argument I once had.
"I've actually investigated some capitalist accusations and found little 
foundations in reality. For instance capitalists love to cite that the 
death tolls of the holodomor  as around 7mil. This statistic actually has 
its origins in Nazi propagandists for the purpose of making Hitler look 
better than Stalin under the premise of that Hitler killed 6mil in 4yrs 
Stalin killed 7mil in 1yr, Hitler is therefore better than Stalin. Now if 
the questionable origins of this statistic aren't enough an historical 
analysis of Ukrainian population growth can provide clear evidence against 
it. In 1926 the population of ethnic Ukrainians was 23,218,860 and then 
13yrs later the population was 23,667,509. Now looking at this it becomes 
evident that the Holodomor did indeed happen to some magnitude else the 
ethnic Ukrainian annual growth rate was 34,511people/year. But when we 
account for this statistic of Holodomor 1932-1933 death tolls then the 
population of that year would be around 16,158,860 with full recovery to 
Pre-famine levels by 1939. Implying an annual growth rate of 1.25mil/year, 
you may look at this and say,"That sounds reasonable." but when you compare 
this with Ukrainian growth rates during the later half of the century you 
observe that during the 60's the decade growth rate was 3.84mil/decade with 
an average annual growth rate of .384mil/year, that during the 70's the 
decade growth rate was 2.88mil/decade with an average annual growth rate of 
.288mi/year, and during the 80's the decade growth rate was 1.92mil/decade 
with an average annual growth rate of .192mil/year. These are far smaller 
growth rates at a much later period than the 30's annual growth rate of 
1.25mil/year. What this indicates is that either this statistic for 
Holodomor death tolls is completely inaccurate for it would imply a 
Pre-industrial growth rate far exceeding that of several Post-industrial 
growth rates, which is absolutely ludicrous. Or it indicates that Stalinist 
policies of collectivizing agriculture are 5 times more beneficial than any 
capitalist agricultural policy. Leaving you to choose between the lesser of 
two "evils" on what the actual truth is, either your a liar or you believe 
in idiotic policies."

comments.text:
#1 I'm sorry if I came off as a troll; I'm not looking for conflict, I was 
challenging your claims because I sincerely disagreed with them. When you 
replied to BoxaBole, you wrote, "its in your interest to have Ukraine taken 
by the EU." Granted, BoxaBole said he/she is from Serbia, but whether it's 
Serbia or Ukraine, you have no right to tell a foreigner what's in their 
country's interest, only they can decide that. (It was also kind of a dick 
move to add the smiley faces when you were telling him/her that they 
basically had no choice in the matter; if that's the case, you shouldn't be 
happy about it, it's a tragic thing for someone to be powerless to decide 
the fate of their own country).

#2 I respect the fact that you tell it like it is. Too many people are too 
easily disillusioned by their country's bullshit explanations for what in 
the end is simply conquest. However, you come off as being content with 
this, which is part of the reason why I accused you of thinking 
imperialistically (meaning your thinking seems to be very much in line with 
imperialism). Maybe that's going a little far, if so, I apologize, but if 
you go back and read your comments objectively, you can see how what you 
wrote implies imperialism.

#3 and #4 The "moral ideal" is the "will of the people," or possibly a 
third alternative to poverty and servitude (i.e. prosperity and 
independence). I understand this may be unrealistic (that's why it's called 
an ideal), but unrealistic does not mean impossible. Perhaps a truly 
independent Ukraine, or that of any other country currently being forced 
into a subservient position, is just a Disney fantasy, but only in today's 
geopolitical atmosphere. Therefore, "contemplating otherwise" is the first 
step toward changing the geopolitical atmosphere to make that ideal 
achievable. Every political/social accomplishment was possible because 
initially, someone believed it could be.

But maybe our personal amounts of respective optimism and skepticism on 
this issue is the base of where we diverge, and the most we can do is agree 
to disagree. If that's the case, I'll just say this: citizens of powerful 
countries like us should not be content with the injustice our countries' 
force on others in their pursuits of power, but subject them to criticism 
and actively try to change them, no matter how unrealistic that may seem or 
how long it will take. That's all we can do. If we don't, who will? And how 
can we expect to better our countries or make the world a better place if 
we don't strive toward those ideals and utilize what free speech and 
opportunities our governments grant us?

That is all, sorry if I got a little preachy there.
comments.author: Gage Dubraski

comments.text:
+Gage Dubraski *#1* You're apparently a troll looking for conflict. I did 
*not* say its in Ukraine's interest to join the EU. I said its in the 
interest of the EU to have Ukraine in its sphere (rather than Russia's). 
Not necessarily in the EU, certainly not anytime soon. Ukraine can not hope 
to join the EU for at least another 20 years, in my opinion. Probably more. 
As for the Eurozone... best not even think that far ahead.

*#2* Yes, I used the words "conquest" and "taken", not because I have an 
"impreialistic way of thinking" whatever the hell that means, but because I 
dislike euphemisms. That's what's happening: the US and the EU are 
effectively "conquering" Ukraine through a coup. Whether that's better or 
worse for the Ukraine in the long run... who can say.

*#3* Yes of course it isn't "right" to force Ukraine into the EU, from a 
strictly democratic perspective... but what is "right"? What is the "moral 
ideal" when you have to choose between poverty and servitude? And what is 
the "will of the people" when social analysts and poll researchers can 
accurately predict how much money one must invest to have the masses vote 
one way or the other? Its just a matter of how much money you have/are 
willing to spend on advertising.

*#4* yes, the Ukraine *has* to be a satellite. Just like everyone else. 
Deal. To contemplate otherwise is Disney fantasy.
comments.author: dIRECT0R

comments.text:
+dIRECT0R You said it was in the Ukraine's interest to be part of the EU, 
and you used the words "conquest" (in your original comment) and "taken." 
That implies a very imperialistic way of thinking. The basic principle of 
the "white man's burden" argument was that it is better for other peoples 
to be conquered by Europeans than for them to be independent. By claiming 
that it is in the interest of Ukraine to be "taken" by the EU, without any 
consideration for the aspirations of its people, you are following the same 
logic. Even if it is economically beneficial for the Ukrainian people to be 
part of the EU, it isn't right if it isn't their choice; again, the moral 
ideal is that they develop their own identity that isn't defined by the EU 
or Russia.

Now if you want to argue only for what is in the EU's interest, and not 
Ukraine's, that at least is credible. However, I'm saying that to only be 
focused on the EU's interests without any concern for what the Ukrainian 
people desire is pretty fucked up. While I realize that politics is a 
fucked up world, and that it may only be realistic to assume that Ukraine 
can only decide between being a satellite of the EU or Russia, that isn't 
how it should be and that isn't how it has to be. And no matter how 
idealistic, somebody has to speak out for what the moral ideal is if it's 
within the range of possibility.

comments.text:
I agree that what Obama said regarding an elected leader being deposed is 
bullshit, and that the US, or any country for that matter, doesn't 
necessarily care whether its allies are dictatorships or not. However, I 
think you're making a lot of assumptions claiming that the CIA was behind 
the developments in Ukraine and all those other countries you mentioned. It 
wouldn't surprise me that the CIA played some sort of role in some of those 
cases, but I would say "natural" revolutions occur much more often since 
orchestrating a revolution and mobilizing thousands of people living in 
another country from the outside, while trying to keep your involvement a 
secret, is obviously pretty fucking difficult, and would never work unless 
everything was perfectly in place. However, if you know of any evidence 
(and I mean from good, not-totally-biased sources) to suggest that this was 
the case for the CIA in Ukraine, please share.

Also, I'm a citizen of the US, and obviously the interests of my country 
and yours are in alignment on this issue, but personally, I would prefer to 
see Ukraine not conquered by anybody and a political administration arise 
that represents the interests of its people, whether they are pro-EU/US or 
not. They seem largely divided on whether they stand with the EU or Russia 
as you get between Crimea and the rest of the country, but I am hoping that 
some sort of peaceful resolution that works for every party involved can be 
reached, and as John said, the ideal is that Ukraine can develop its own 
identity and not be defined by whoever it affiliates itself with 
politically.

comments.text:
+Julia May First, I am aware that +Benoit Robitaille is not some kind of 
hive consciousness that speaks for the entireity of Russia nor is he 
apparently Russian, I merely wanted to have a discussion on his opinion as 
I find irredentism and independence movements a very interesting topic. 

I have heard of Vladivostok and am aware that some people do live in 
Eastern Russia. I just wanted to pre-empt any claim that the reason there 
are no independence movements is that no one lives there. That is somewhat 
beside the point though, considering my main question was whether or not 
there are independence movements. 

+Benoit Robitaille Um, if you're not actually from a place or know it very 
well, it's probably a bit risky to claim you know how people identify, much 
less make generalisations. For example, people in the Falkland Islands are 
far more patriotic about being British than I am, despite the fact they 
live half a world away. 

Identity is all about history and a vast array of other factors. Inner 
London is probably about as different from North Yorkshire as Glasgow is, 
yet a Londoner and Yorkshiremen will identify as British whereas a Scotsman 
is less likely to. 

God this is a long comment...sorry.

The term 'Europe' can be geographical or political depending on the 
context. For example, in the UK, 'Europe' is often referred as if it's a 
different continent. This isn't because people think the UK is in Africa or 
something, but generally in reference to the EU or just things specific to 
the mainland. 

In Russia I imagine it's a similar case. With the term 'Europe' being 
associated more with western and central Europe when used in a political 
context. I could be wrong though.

comments.text:
I personally see this as a problem on both sides. On one hand, yea, Crimea 
doesn't have the constitutional legitimacy to secede and if Russia were to 
annex it then it would cause a shitstorm. And on the other side, the new 
government is trying to force the Ukrainian language on these regions. 
However, I think it's fair to look at the reasons behind these both.

Crimea wants to secede because they have a rather large pro-Russia base but 
ALSO because right now there are a LOT of Russian soldiers in Crimea (The 
"unmarked" soldiers have been seen driving vehicles with Russian plates 
and, quite honestly, they are WAY too geared and too well trained to be 
anything BUT a military force from another country, and the only nation who 
would have a reason to do this would be Russia). If you point a loaded gun 
to someone's head and threaten to kill them unless they say something, you 
can bet you can make them say it. There can be pro-Russian people who DON"T 
want to secede, but you won't hear from them because they fear speaking up 
will make them targets). These two things are what makes things even more 
problematic. Is this referendum driven by their own desire, or is it 
because right now there are a lot of military personnel in the region that 
want them to join Russia (Something Russia wants, due to the naval base 
they have in the region: it's Russia's only naval base that doesn't freeze 
up at some point in the year).

The new government right now is actually really afraid. Them trying to 
force the Ukrainian language on the Russian-speaking regions is driven by 
this fear. What are they afraid of? Well, for starters, the protesters. 
These protesters weren't as peaceful as it seems, especially during the 
final couple of weeks, and the government is afraid of what'd happen if 
they start up again. Because of this, they're trying to force all Russian 
influence out of the nation. Does this make it right? No, but what matters 
is understanding the root cause of it.

Either way, both are problems. They just come from different sides. This 
isn't easily solved, and is only being made worse by the actions of the USA 
and Russia.

comments.text:
Ukraine existed before in the form of Kieven Rus (which included Belarus, 
and a small part of Russia). After the fall of Kieven Rus, few successor 
principalities emerged that represented territories of modern Ukraine 
(principality of Kiev, Volyn-Halych, Pereyaslavl, and few other small 
ones). Later, territory of Ukraine became part of Rzeczpospolita 
(Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth), until Ukrainians rebelled and formed 
semi-independent state of Cossack Hetmanate (which became a Russian Vassal 
State). Hetmanate existed for just over 100 years, until it was fully 
annexed by Russia in 18th century. However, Hetmanate is the beginning of 
the modern Ukrainian nation. By this point, the Southwestern territories of 
Kieven Rus have developed a culture, language, customs, politics etc, which 
significantly differed from Northeastern territories of Kieven Rus. In 
1917, three states emerged: Western Ukrainian Republic, Ukrainian People’s 
Republic, and Ukrainian Socialist Republic. Ukrainian Socialist Republic, 
with the help of Russia, fought and conquered the other two states. In 
1922, Ukrainian Socialist Republic signed a union treaty with Russian 
Socialist Republic, and two other Socialist Republics to form Union of 
Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR). Hopefully that helps to clarify few 
things :-)

better than Stalin under the premise of that Hitler killed 6mil in 4yrs

the questionable origins of this statistic aren't enough an historical 
analysis of Ukrainian population growth can provide clear evidence against 
it. In 1926 the population of ethnic Ukrainians was 23,218,860 and then 
13yrs later the population was 23,667,509. Now looking at this it becomes 
evident that the Holodomor did indeed happen to some magnitude else the 
ethnic Ukrainian annual growth rate was 34,511people/year. But when we 
account for this statistic of Holodomor 1932-1933 death tolls then the 
population of that year would be around 16,158,860 with full recovery to 
Pre-famine levels by 1939. Implying an annual growth rate of 1.25mil/year,

comments.text:
You know what I'm against? I'm against Serbians, Russians, and any other 
nationality dictating how we run our country. I'm against people telling me 
what I'm allowed to believe, how I'm allowed to feel, and where my 
loyalties must lay. As a ukrainian, my blood boils when everybody who has 
never lived a day in their life in Ukraine, yet has stands here and 
criticizes the vast majority of my people because they disagree with you.

I am not afraid to admit when I am wrong, and in this case, I was wrong 
about nationalism. I have always thought nationalism is a great quality to 
have. And I see I was wrong.

The reason I now see it that way, is because I have seen the bigger 
picture. There is a population much bigger and much more nationalist than 
Ukraine. It's the Slavic community altogether.

You are so so much more concerned with a Slavic brotherhood staying intact, 
that you don't care about the people as individuals. The Slavic community, 
mostly Russians, have displayed such severe nationalism, they are more than 
happy to wage a war against another Slavic country in order to keep a 
Slavic country from working well with Europe.

I have lived in Europe, USA, and Ukraine, and although I never lived in 
Russia, I have family there and stayed there for months at a time. Of all 
these places, if I were to choose which countries ukraine should be more 
like, I would choose the western countries. I say this with my 12 siblings 
who still live in Ukraine, in mind.

comments.text:
+Jakov Nenadovic Well, my experience of naitonalism is being half-English, 
half-Welsh, but born and raised in Wales, and having a neutral

ones who were friends with people they liked, and the nationalists, who 
were friends with only Welsh people they liked. Of course, because I had 
the wrong accent, I was supposedly English, even though I'd only ever spent 
a total of about 20 days there in my life (and was born in Wales). That 
same nationalism is what is threatening my mother's job because she has the 
wrong language, even though she has very Welsh ancestry, she was raised in 
Australia, and is therefore somehow English in the eyes of the 
nationalists. Never mind every Welsh person can speak English, and no one 
outside Wales speaks Welsh, if you aren't bilingual, your job is at risk.

Now I love my country, and I am fully behind the preservation of the Welsh 
language, and most of my closest friends are Welsh, I think of myself as 
Welsh. It is my home, and the home of most of my ancestors, but the 
Nationalists say I am a foreigner, and they are threatening the livelihood 
of my mother for no better reason than that they consider her foreign. That 
kind of mindless Xenophobia makes my blood boil - someone implying I don't 
have the right to live in my own land. Fuck that.

Patriotism is fine. Political awareness is pretty much a duty. Preserving 
your culture, celebrating your identity, and stopping your country from 
being pushed around is great. Nationalism though... no, fuck that.

comments.text:
I'd like to elaborate a little bit on this whole "Nazis in Ukraine" 
situation. Most of them probably don't qualify as such, they are rather 
ultranationalist, which is not, technically speaking, nazism, but comes 
very close, in my opinion.

During WWII, the German forces created a division of the SS (Schutzstaffel) 
from Ukrainian volunteers in the Western Ukraine. They fought for Hitler 
against the USSR until almost the end of war. Now they are considered 
heroes in the Western Ukraine. In the city of Lvov/Lviv, the largest there, 
there is an annual parade in honour of that division, with thousands of 
people cheering for them. For the guys that fought for Hitler.

Around that time, there existed an "Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists" 
(OUN), which technically declared fighting against everyone for the 
independence of Ukraine, however, repeatedly acknowledge that their main 
enemy was the USSR and had made a deal with Hitler to leave each other 
alone. Those people had attempted a genocide of Polish population, having 
declared certain territories "Ukrainian" and demanding that ethnic Poles 
leave that area within one or two days or otherwise be killed. By various 
accounts, in a few years the organisation murdered, if I am not mistaken, 
from 30 to 60 thousand Polish civilians, not discriminating by age or 
gender, simply because the lived (and may have lived for the past couple 
hundred years) on the territories that were now deemed "Ukrainian". These 
people, the OUN, are also nowadays considered heroes. In 2009, 
then-president Yushenko awarded the highest state award to the leaders of 
that organisation (again who committed genocide and made deals with Hitler) 
- those awards were later withdrawn by the following government. But still, 
Western Ukrainians now consider them heroes.

This organisation, the OUN, coined the slogan "Glory to Ukraine! - Glory to 
heroes", which has recently become popular again with all these protests. 
Most people, sadly, don't realise that they are honouring murderers and 
Nazi collaborators. Instead, they insist that "definitions have changed" 
and now this phrase honours just "any people fighting for Ukraine". Like, 
you know, the popular German phrase "Sieg heil!", which translates as "Hail 
victory!" and refers not to military victories specifically, but any 
"victory", like scientific progress, social advancement, etc.

Now, the people in the East and in the South of Ukraine are different. We 
have always been taught that Hitler was bad. Sure, Stalin wasn't amazing 
either, but if I were asked who was worse, for me the answer is obvious. As 
a result, all those who refer to Hitler collaborators and supporters as 
"heroes" are not exactly people who we enjoy too much. This is why whenever 
there is an election of any kind, the country becomes polarised.

The problem of language, of course, is another very important issue. 
Russian-speaking population is concentrated in the East and South, but it 
is concentrated there very densely, especially in urban areas. Two largest 
Eastern cities, Kharkov and Donetsk, have 1.5 and 1 million people, 
respectively, and AT LEAST 99% there speak Russian, yet the Russian 
language has literally no special rights there, no more than English or 
Swahili. If you go to a cinema, all foreign movies are shown only with 
Ukrainian dubbing (and not too great, at that), and all Russian movies are 
shown with Ukrainian subtitles, which makes it even more ridiculous. If you 
go to any government establishment for any reason, even though every single 
person there speaks Russian, you'll be forced to fill in all the forms in 
Ukrainian. If you buy medication, instructions are there in Ukrainian only, 
which constitutes problems for older people, who often don't understand it 
very well. If you open a business and try to give it a Russian name, it may 
create some additional bureaucratic problems for you. Last winter I was 
writing my master's thesis in the university in Donetsk. I was not allowed 
to write or present it in Russian. In fact, I was given an option to choose 
English, German or French if I wanted to (and, of course, Ukrainian), but 
not Russian, no.

So, for the past twenty years, people in the East despise the government 
for either ignoring the language problem altogether or promising to do 
something and then not doing it at all. Only the last government of 
Yanukovich did finally create a law about "regional languages", which, 
technically, did allow for some possibilities for the Russian language. It 
was a very bad law, it was ridiculously ineffective and it didn't bring any 
apparent changes. But at least it existed. (also, note that it didn't refer 
specifically to Russian, but to any minority language) When the new 
government came to power after the coup in February 2014, the parliament 
became under its control, as many people from the party of the previous 
president either fled the city fearing for their lives, or changed sides. 
So, what does the "new" parliament do? Well, LITERALLY on their very first 
day, they repeal that law. That, in my opinion, was the last straw that 
sparked the protests in the South and East, especially in Crimea, which 
later gave Russia the excuse to go there. The law, by the way, was returned 
in a few weeks, I think, but by that time it was far too late.

So yeah... quite a long text I got here for a random youtube comment... but 
here you go, an opinion from a person from Eastern Ukraine who disapproves 
of the original Kiev protests and the February coup.
comments.author: Артём Высоцкий

comments.text:
+Jakov Nenadovic Russia has no right to invade Ukraine. And it is fucking 
irresponsible for them to do so. I have absolutely no doubt that the West 
has been manipulating Ukraine for years, in fact since the end of the Cold 
War. Equally, I have no doubt that Russia has been doing the same. However, 
Russia can not actually seize land like that, if only because it escalates 
the conflict into military action and risks retaliation from the West. 
Think what that would look like... a war with Russia over such a stupid 
little squabble. millions of people could potentially die, and the 
'leaders' who started it would be just fine. We have for decades only 
fought the kind of enemy that can't afford a real air force. I don't think 
many people have any real conception of what a modern World War would look 
like. If you fight another developed nation with modern technology, you 
won't have a lingering occupation against petty insurgency, you will lay 
waste to continents. Nothing is worth that kind of loss.

What I think should happen in these situations is that referenda on 
independence should be called for a year or two down the road, and 
agreements drawn that both sides will provoke no further disturbance in the 
meantime, so everyone can calm the fuck down and remove the threat of war. 
Then, if there really is a majority in the east that wants to join Russia, 
they can show through clean, independently monitored elections, and get 
their wish. Not everyone will be happy, but these spur of the moment 
referenda are not at all legitimate, no more than the Svoboda coup was. It 
proves nothing, and is just intended to provide a pretext for further 
military action.
comments.author: tSp289

-Protestors had a fare share of weapons from west part of the country, 
where far right movement activists were raiding police posts. 
-Yanukovich and opposition on 21st of February, organised by EU signed an 
agreement to end political crisis. Yanukovich agreed to that, because of 
the shooting. Among many things that agreement required both parties to 
leave streets of Kiev. However when Ukrainian police did so, protesters 
instead of going home as agreed, started taking over key buildings and 
control. At the same time Ukrainian president fled the country.
-Russia still does not recognise temporary government, because no official 
impeachment procedure was ever made and technically Yanukovich is still a 
president. Russian position was that a coup organised partially by 
nationalists, who now openly demanded to do all sort of nasty things to be 
done to the ethnic Russians in the east. 

Few other examples, not as important to what is happening but still:
-John also mentioned that poisoning skyrocketed since Putin came to power, 
but Litvinenko aside (and still not proven, only allegations), I don't know 
of a single case when something like that would occur.
-Another line that I is inaccurate is when John mention that when in 2006 
Russia cut off gas supply to Ukraine only because of its "friendliness with 
the west". He forgot to mention that previously Ukraine, was receiving a 
billion dollar worth of gas discount, paying third of what rest of Europe 
was. When Ukraine and its new leader decided to break close ties with 
Russia and get very close with Europe, there was no political/economical 
reason for Russia to continue offering that discount. Problem started when 
Ukraine refused to pay any price increases and to seek any compromises. 
That angered Kremlin, who was already fuming with the whole "revolution" a 
year earlier right in its backyard. Eventually Gazprom, said you either pay 
what we say or find your gas somewhere else. You know how that story ended. 
Russia switched the gas for a bit, Ukraine had no choice, but to accept new 
tariff, which still were a third less than what Europe was paying.

P.S. and there is so much more to say.

comments.text:
+Garet Rooks

1) Ukraine has been part of Russia for hundreds of years, except for the 
last 50 or so years.
2) Its culture is extremely inter linked.
3) A vast number of people living in Ukraine are ethnic Russian, and plenty 
of people speak Russian.
4) The democratically elected (indeed, you don't know how democratic the 
elections were in the first place, but meh) was toppled, with the clear 
support of the US behind it.
5) Russia provided Ukraine with very significant financial aid. (WAY more 
in terms of fuel subsidies in total value than all the financial help the 
US and the EU pledged to give to Ukraine IF it privatised its industries, 
no doubt for Western companies to come swooping in)
6) Russia was a very sure fuel source for Ukraine, and a very important 
trade partner. 
7) The protests themselves were thought to have been aggravated by outside 
sources.


Likewise, some points to go against the West:

1) The Propaganda was disgustingly obvious. Everyday I would see and hear 
of news outlets barely stopping short of outright insulting Putin and 
calling him an imbecile. Every major news outlet adopted a hugely 
subjective tone. Zero objectivity was present...
2) The US is no longer classified as any sort of Democracy by top 
universities in the world. It is now an outright oligarchy; and yet US 
media vehemently support the idea that Russia's oligarchy has to fall.
3) The US has toppled democratically elected governments to be replaced 
with dictatorships due to corporate lobbying (thus the term bana republic 
was born).
4) The US has puppeted countless countries, but simply hasn't annexed them, 
leaving them to economic ruin after invasion, and allowing US corporations 
to come swooping in. Russia annexes a territory full of Russians that is 
important to the country's NEAR HOME geopolitical security and immediately 
announces a very hefty investment plan.

Honestly, I'm being completely objective here. I might sound extremely 
suggestive and opinionated, but the END RESUTLS speak for themselves, 
really. I don't think states are inherently evil; they're just playing 'the 
game'. However, it is obvious whose fault is in this case...
comments.author: Caius Filimon

comments.text:
+LigaderLegenden No problem man! Sorry for being petty, sometimes that can 
get the best of me. I just do not enjoy being stereotyped with being 
American. My countrymen do need to get their things in order, but some of 
us are alright. ^^ I do understand though why you jump to the defense of 
other countries in such a circumstance. We have a big problem with 
xenophobia here in America.

Most of the sources I have found come from the tribes, so I am sure there 
is some bias in there. Losing parties in history can be rather sore and 
sometimes exaggerate. It is why I do not consider it a genocide, as there 
was not intent. It was just typical of the era really. I have found Russian 
sources on this in the past, but they tend to describe the fur traders as 
wild men who did not represent Russia very well. I agree with them 
personally, Russia has been, and continues to be, very particular about how 
it carries itself.

I honestly try to be fair as possible, and look at all perspectives of a 
historic topic. Though a good deal of sources can be trusted, bias does pop 
up occasionally.

comments.text:
+LigaderLegenden http://www.apiai.org/culture-history/history/

"The early Russian period was a devastating time for Unangax. By 1800, 
little more than 50 years after first Russian contact, the Unangax 
population had been reduced by some 80 percent, to about 2,500 people. 
Battles between Unangax and Russians, Russian atrocities, forced Unangax 
labor, and introduced diseases all took their toll, and no part of 
traditional Unangax culture was left unchanged. In the realm of 
subsistence, many traditional activities continued through this time, but 
some important shifts took place. Because many men were forced to work for 
fur-hunting companies in the region, women and children took on increasing 
responsibilities for providing their families with foods and resources.
With population loss came far fewer occupied settlements and the 
consolidation and relocation of many villages. By the end of the Russian 
era in 1867, only approximately 17 Unangax communities remained, a number 
that, with some fluctuation, declined until today. At the same time, social 
and religious changes were also imposed. The earlier matrilineal kinship 
system fell apart. Traditional leadership structures were used by Russian 
colonizers for their own purposes, with Unangax leaders soon finding 
themselves serving in the often difficult role of middlemen between their 
own people and the dominant Russian economic interests. Hand in hand with 
these changes came a new religion, Russian Orthodoxy. By the later 
eighteenth century, even before the first Russian Orthodox priests had 
arrived from Russia, Unangax were being baptized into the church by Russian 
laymen, and Russian Orthodoxy quickly became the sole religion of the 
region."

Every nation has done crimes, why would Russia deserve special treatment 
when discussing such things? 
Now, what was that you were saying about spreading misinformation? ;)

If you require further reading let me know, I have a wealth of sources =) 
Though I am sure you are more than capable in researching the topic. Next 
time think twice before accusing someone of spreading lies... Especially if 
you have not looked heavily into the subject material.

comments.text:
+Dania H
Excerpt from an argument I once had.
"You demand that I prove these statistics but you dont prove any of your 
statistics you just vomit them out like you're some sort of entitled 
statistics god. I've actually investigated some capitalist accusations and 
found little foundations in reality. For instance capitalists love to cite 
that the death tolls of the holodomor  as around 7mil. This statistic 
actually has its origins in Nazi propagandists for the purpose of making 
Hitler look better than Stalin under the premise of that Hitler killed 6mil 
in 4yrs Stalin killed 7mil in 1yr, Hitler is therefore better than Stalin. 
Now if the questionable origins of this statistic aren't enough an 
historical analysis of Ukrainian population growth can provide clear 
evidence against it. In 1926 the population of ethnic Ukrainians was 
23,218,860 and then 13yrs later the population was 23,667,509. Now looking 
at this it becomes evident that the Holodomor did indeed happen to some 
magnitude else the ethnic Ukrainian annual growth rate was 
34,511people/year. But when we account for this statistic of Holodomor 
1932-1933 death tolls then the population of that year would be around 
16,158,860 with full recovery to Pre-famine levels by 1939. Implying an 
annual growth rate of 1.25mil/year, you may look at this and say,"That 
sounds reasonable." but when you compare this with Ukrainian growth rates 
during the later half of the century you observe that during the 60's the 
decade growth rate was 3.84mil/decade with an average annual growth rate of 
.384mil/year, that during the 70's the decade growth rate was 
2.88mil/decade with an average annual growth rate of .288mi/year, and

top_comment.text:
Crimea's history goes back a bit further. The Tatars (of Turkish ethnicity) 
were the first documented colonisers of Crimea. When the Ottoman Empire 
emerged, they were essentially left alone (being allied to Turkey) and for 
over a hundred years were the main suppliers of Slavs for the Ottoman 
Empire's slave trade, running frequent raids into Eastern Ukraine and 
western Russia.

Catherine the Great arrived, and Russia spent much of the next 170 years 
killing / starving / forcibly migrating Tatars from the territory and 
moving Russians in (OK, you can justify them doing it to begin with, but 
isn't 170 years a bit long to be taking your revenge on a population?). It 
was only with Gorbachov's Perestroika reforms that some Tatars started 
moving back, with more following Ukraine's independence - although still 
relatively small in number, as obviously by-and-large they couldn't return 
to their ancestral homes.

Meanwhile, with Ukraine as a whole, I've heard rumours that during 
Yanukovich's negotiations with the EU and Russia, Russia was open to 
tripartite negotiations but the EU wasn't.  Whether that's true or not, if 
Ukraine had been able to engage in tripartite negotiations for some money 
from both the EU and Russia, that may have quelled both camps - especially 
if Ukraine stated from the outset that while it was interested in trade 
agreements / economic alliances, it wouldn't join a political alliance on 
either side.

More recently, when the two Eastern provinces unilaterally declared their 
independence, Kiev reacted in just about the worst way you could expect 
them to if they were interested in maintaining the unity of the country 
(which you'd think they'd want given the two regions are the economic 
powerhouse of Ukraine), with shelling towns and the Odessa debacle. Then 
again, there are elements in the separatist factions who yearn for the old 
soviet days when the economy was stronger but dissenting opinions from the 
leadership's were discouraged (to put it mildly).

As with the events of WWII, it's likely the majority of the population are 
caught in a catch-22 situation: do you ally with the tyrant in the West or 
the tyrant in the East? In WWII, even if they didn't support either, when 
the relevant tyrant's armies started marching into the country, it made 
sense to at least pretend to be allied with them to maximise their chances 
of staying alive and being left alone. Of course, if a town was occupied by 
first one group then the other, things got complicated...﻿

Russia's actions are because Chevron signed a deal with Ukraine to start 
fracking in the western regions of Ukraine. By 2020 Ukrainian officials 
expected the country would be able to sustain it's energy needs and 
possibly export natural gas to the EU. Ukraine has begun signing trade 
agreements with the EU, they are scheduled to finalize after the elections 
on May 25th. The rest of this statement is my opinion. I think Russia is 
worried about their pipelines in Ukraine. They have three major pipelines 
going through Ukraine. These pipelines account for about 10% of their hard 
currency acquired each year. If Ukraine is self sufficient they control 10% 
of Russia's income per year. Russia has enjoyed having leverage on the EU. 
Russia supplies the EU with most of its natural gas needs. People in Russia 
are still mad about the break up of the soviet union. There is a sentiment 
that Russia should reunite the USSR. Ukrainians in the west want better 
lives. They are tired of being pawns. Russia is 55th in terms of standard 
of living and Ukraine is 74th. A lot of western Ukrainians feel that their 
best hope for a better future lie with the EU. Russia sees Ukraine joining 
the EU as one step closer to joining NATO. ﻿

captions.text:
Good morning, Hank, it's Tuesday.
I want to talk about Ukraine today, but this

is extremely complicated and I just want to
apologize in advance for anything that I get

wrong / leave out / over-simplify.
Okay? Okay!

So this is Ukraine, the second largest country
in Europe by area. And this is the Crimean

Peninsula, which saw much of the fighting
in the Crimean War that lasted from 1853 to

It was sort of a 'Catholic versus Orthodox'
thing, but the larger cause was Europe fearing

that Russia's power would expand as the Ottoman
empire declined.

So Britain, France, and the kinda-still-a-thing
Ottoman Empire teamed up to eventually defeat

Russia and five hundred thousand people died,
and it was generally pretty awful, and obviously

resolved very little since Europe - just sixty
years later - would go ahead and have World

War I. Then towards the end of World War I,
Russia had its famous communist revolution

and Ukraine enjoyed a brief period of independence.
Although 'enjoyed' may not be quite the right

verb. In fact from 1917 to 1921 Ukraine was
mired in endless wars among competing factions

including Poland and the USSR and Ukrainian
Nationalists, even some real live anarchists.

It was all very complicated. It was also extremely
violent.

More than 1.5 million people died. And then
finally Ukraine became part of the USSR, and

things became more stable for a while, but
then... Stalin.

As many as 10 million Ukrainians starved to
death in 1932 and 1933 thanks to Stalin's

agricultural policies, which were not just
stupid but also actively evil. I mean, there

was widespread starvation in a country that
is now the world's third largest exporter

of grain. Then following World War II, Stalin
forcibly deported the Crimean peninsula's

entire indigenous population of ethnic Tatars
to central Asia. So if you wanna point to

one individual who's responsible for a lot
of this, I don't wanna, you know, call anyone

out, but STALIN. Stalin also moved many ethnic
Russians into Ukraine, especially into the

Crimean peninsula in the western part of the
country, which is the industrial center. And

then Stalin's successor, Khrushchev, decided
to transfer the Crimean peninsula from Russia

to Ukraine in 1954. Why? Well, Khrushchev
had lots of ties to Ukraine, but also the

Crimean peninsula is not actually physically
attached to Russia.

As you can see here, it is physically attached
to Ukraine and it gets all of its electricity

and water from Ukraine, and it's easier to
administer places you are physically connected

to. Which is why Alaska should be part of
Canada, but that is a different story. Okay,

so quick contemporary demographic snapshot:
today, about 67% of people living in Ukraine

speak Ukrainian as their first language. About
30% speak Russian, although only about 17%

of the population identify as ethnically Russian.
And as you can see here Russian is mostly

spoken in the West (he meant East) and in
the Crimean peninsula. Many Tatars have returned

to Crimea since the breakup of the Soviet
Union, but today they only make up about 12%
of the population.

Okay, so flash forward to December of 1991
after the Soviet Union has broken up: Ukraine

has had a nationwide referendum and 90% of
people, including a majority of those living

in the Crimean peninsula, voted for independence
from Russia. But Ukraine remained much more

closely aligned with Russia than many other
former Soviet Republics did like, for instance,

Estonia, which is now part of the European
Union. In 2004 there was an election and there

were widespread reports of vote-rigging, but
the Russian-friendly Viktor Yanukovych was

elected. The opposition leader, Viktor Yushchenko,
lead massive street protests in Kiev that

came to be known as the Orange Revolution.
That opposition leader, Yushchenko, was disfigured

and almost died as a result of mysterious
poisoning. Side note, but the number of "mysterious

poisonings" in Russia and Eastern Europe has
absolutely skyrocketed since Putin came to
power in Russia, which I'm sure is a coincidence.

Anyway, the Orange Revolution protests led
to a second election, and the poisoned opposition

leader, Yushchenko, won, and yay, everything
would be made of puppies and freedom and rainbows

and friendliness toward Europe forever, except
NO.

For one thing, a lot of people in Ukraine,
especially in the western part, want to be

more closely allied with Russia, and also
(despite being an economist) Yushchenko wasn't

very good at running the Ukrainian economy.
Also, Yushchenko couldn't push through austerity

measures needed to deal with Ukraine's rising
debt, and his friendliness towards Europe

infuriated Russia, which cut off gas supplies
briefly (but disastrously) to Ukraine in 2006.

So, by 2010, Ukraine was being led by the
Europe friendly, and somewhat corrupt, Yulia

Tymoshenko and then there were elections.
And the presidential election, declared free

and fair by international observers, was won
by the aforementioned, Russian-friendly, Viktor

Yanukovych. In November 2013, Yanukovych announced
that Ukraine would abandon an agreement to

strengthen ties with the EU and would instead
become a closer ally of Russia.

And that is when the protests began in Kiev's
Independence Square. Those protests grew and

grew until February 20th when dozens of protesters
were killed by military and police and the

next day Yanukovych disappeared from Kiev.
The protesters had won. They installed a new

temporary government to prepare for new elections...
and then the Putin regime marched into the

Crimean Peninsula, ostensibly to protect ethnic
Russians there and Russian military installations,

but this violation of Ukraine's territorial
integrity is known in diplomatic circles as,
like, "a big 'effing deal."

Crimea is already an autonomous province with
its own government, so what does it want?

Does it want independence? That would be hard,
all of their electricity and water has to

come through Ukraine. Does it want to be part
of Russia again? That would be impossible,

without Ukrainian co-operation, which right
now seems inconceivable, so that's where we

are right now. I mean, unless something has
happened in the last 30 minutes. So here's

one narrative of these events: an unpopular
and ineffective, but democratically elected

politician was removed from power by a mob
of protesters, and the new, unelected parliament

briefly passed a law saying that only Ukrainian
can be the official language of the country,

even though many people in the country speak
Russian. Furthermore, this new government

wants to become part of the EU which might
bring NATO missiles to Russia's border and

that is unacceptable to Russia. I mean, I'm
American. We've had some very infective and

unpopular leaders, and what we've done is
just waited for them not to be president anymore.

But here's another narrative: a tyrannical
leader who ordered the murder of peaceful

protesters was chased from power and replaced
by a government that will transition Ukraine

toward free and fair elections and Russia
responded to that by invading Ukraine.

Hank, I'm not trying to make a false equivalence
here, but I think it's really important to

understand both of these narratives. And I
wanted to give a little more historical context

than we've been seeing on the news because
it helps us to understand that the pull between

Western Europe and Russia in Ukraine is not
new. I mean, the word "Ukraine" itself means

"borderland". It has for centuries functioned
as the border between West and East. What

Ukraine needs is stability... decades of stability,
so it can grow to have its own identity to

have relationships with both Europe and Russia
without being controlled by either. Right

now that dream seems really far away but 60
years ago Japan was in ruins. 25 years ago

Germany was divided into two countries. 12
years ago Sierra Leone was mired in a horrific

and seemingly endless civil war but today
it's the second fastest growing economy in

the world. The arc of history is long, Hank,
let's hope that it bends towards peace. Hank,
I'll see you on Friday.

title: Understanding Ukraine: The Problems Today and Some Historical Context
